data.title: Czech premier resigns from office
data.text:
Vladimir Spidla narrowly survived a vote of confidence within his party

Czech Prime Minister Vladimir Spidla has officially resigned after his party's performance in the European elections.

Mr Spidla offered his resignation to President Vaclav Klaus, who will lead talks on forming a new government.

Mr Spidla announced last weekend he would stand down after he lost support within his Social Democrat Party.

His successor as party leader, former interior minister Stanislav Gross, met Mr Klaus on Thursday.

Speaking after the meeting, Mr Gross, a former train technician, told reporters he wanted to build a government which would last until the 2006 elections and would not rely on Communist support.

He said he would continue seeking a parliamentary majority for such a cabinet.

Mr Klaus has asked Mr Spidla and his outgoing coalition government, which also includes the centrist Christian Democrats and the right-wing Freedom Union, to lead the government until a new one can be formed.

He also thanked Mr Spidla for his work and efforts "in a difficult position of the head of a fragile coalition government."

Vote

Mr Spidla actually survived a vote of confidence within his party, by a narrow margin.

More than 100 of his opponents voted against him, but they failed by six votes to gain the three-fifths majority needed to remove him.

However, the result was poor enough to force him to go.

The confidence vote was called after a disastrous showing by the party in the European elections earlier in June apparently after alienating many traditional left-wing voters with a series of unpopular public finance reforms.

The Social Democrats won only two of the 24 seats at stake.

According to the constitution, the president must now nominate a candidate for prime minister, who must then win a vote of confidence.

Mr Gross, 34, has a reputation of being a skilful negotiator who favours a minority left-wing government with the support of one or more opposition parties.

Mr Klaus has said he would not appoint any government that would have to rely on the Communists for support.

He has also said that if he failed to get agreement on a new government, he could call an early election.
